topic_name: Human Nervous System and Sense Organs

canonical_explanation.text: The nervous system coordinates body activities through electrical impulses. Neurons (nerve cells) consist of cell body (soma), dendrites (receive impulses), and axon (transmit impulses). The CNS includes brain and spinal cord; PNS includes cranial (12 pairs) and spinal nerves (31 pairs). The brain has three main parts: cerebrum (thinking, memory, voluntary actions), cerebellum (balance, coordination), and medulla oblongata (involuntary actions like breathing). The autonomic nervous system has sympathetic (fight or flight) and parasympathetic (rest and digest) divisions. Reflex actions are quick, automatic responses via reflex arcs. The eye forms images through refraction by cornea and lens, with retina containing rods (dim light) and cones (color). The ear has three parts for hearing (external, middle, inner) with the cochlea for sound detection and vestibular apparatus for balance.
rules: CNS: brain + spinal cord; PNS: cranial + spinal nerves
Cerebrum: thinking, memory; Cerebellum: balance; Medulla: involuntary functions
Reflex arc: receptor -> sensory neuron -> relay neuron -> motor neuron -> effector
Eye: cornea, lens, retina (rods and cones), optic nerve
Ear: external (pinna, canal), middle (ossicles), inner (cochlea, vestibular apparatus)

questions.question_text: The structural and functional unit of the nervous system is:
questions.explanation_correct: The neuron is the structural and functional unit of the nervous system. Neurons are specialized cells that transmit electrical signals throughout the body to coordinate its activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Neuron. Neurons are the cells that make up the nervous system and are responsible for receiving, processing, and transmitting electrical signals. They have a cell body, dendrites to receive signals, and an axon to transmit signals. The other options (A, C, and D) are not the structural and functional units of the nervous system.

questions.question_text: The part of a neuron that receives impulses is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The dendrites are the part of the neuron that receives electrical impulses from other neurons or sensory receptors. They are the input end of the neuron, responsible for collecting and transmitting signals to the cell body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The axon is the part of the neuron that transmits electrical impulses away from the cell body to other neurons or effector organs like muscles. The cell body (or soma) contains the nucleus and organelles that keep the neuron alive, but does not directly receive impulses. The myelin sheath is a fatty layer that insulates the axon, allowing faster transmission of signals, but it does not receive impulses.

questions.question_text: The largest part of the human brain is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The cerebrum is the largest part of the human brain, making up about 85% of the brain's total weight. It is responsible for higher functions like thinking, memory, and voluntary actions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum is the correct answer as it is the largest and most prominent part of the human brain. The cerebellum, medulla oblongata, and pons are other important parts of the brain, but they are smaller in size compared to the cerebrum.

questions.question_text: Balance and coordination are controlled by the:
questions.explanation_correct: The cerebellum is responsible for balance and coordination of body movements. It receives information from the muscles, joints, and the inner ear (balance) and helps to coordinate and smoothen out movements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum is involved in higher functions like thinking, memory, and voluntary actions. The medulla oblongata controls involuntary functions like breathing. The hypothalamus is involved in regulating body temperature, hunger, and thirst. But the cerebellum, located at the back of the brain, is the part that specifically controls balance and coordination of body movements.

questions.question_text: A quick, automatic response to a stimulus is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A reflex action is a quick, automatic response to a stimulus. This is because reflex arcs in the nervous system allow the body to respond immediately without any conscious thought or voluntary control.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A reflex action is a quick, automatic response to a stimulus. This is different from a voluntary action, which is a conscious response that you control. Reflex actions happen very quickly through reflex arcs in the nervous system, while conditioned responses and learned behaviors are more complex and take time to develop.

questions.question_text: The light-sensitive layer of the eye is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The retina is the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye that contains the rods and cones, which detect light and convert it into electrical signals that the brain can interpret as vision.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea, lens, and sclera are not the light-sensitive layers of the eye. The cornea is the transparent front part of the eye, the lens is the structure that helps focus light, and the sclera is the white, protective outer layer of the eye. The retina, located at the back of the eye, is the light-sensitive layer that contains the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) that convert light into electrical signals for the brain to process as vision.

questions.question_text: The part of the ear that contains the cochlea is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The inner ear contains the cochlea, which is the part of the ear responsible for detecting sound. The cochlea converts the vibrations from sound waves into electrical signals that the brain can interpret as sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The external ear, middle ear, and Eustachian tube are not the parts of the ear that contain the cochlea. The cochlea is located in the inner ear, which is responsible for the sense of hearing. The inner ear also contains the vestibular system, which is responsible for balance and spatial orientation.

questions.question_text: Involuntary actions like breathing are controlled by the:
questions.explanation_correct: Involuntary actions like breathing are controlled by the medulla oblongata, which is the lower part of the brain stem. The medulla oblongata regulates automatic functions of the body, such as breathing, heartbeat, and blood pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum is responsible for conscious, voluntary actions, while the cerebellum controls balance and coordination. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature, hunger, and other homeostatic functions, but does not directly control involuntary actions like breathing. The medulla oblongata is the correct answer because it is the part of the brain that handles these kinds of automatic, unconscious processes.

questions.question_text: The gap between two neurons is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The gap between two neurons is called the synapse. This is the space across which chemical or electrical signals pass from one neuron to the next, allowing for communication between nerve cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'synapse'. The synapse is the gap or junction between two neurons where signals are transmitted from one cell to the other. It is not the axon (the long projection that carries signals from the cell body), the dendrite (the branched projections that receive signals), or the node of Ranvier (gaps in the myelin sheath of the axon).

questions.question_text: How many pairs of cranial nerves are there?
questions.explanation_correct: The human nervous system has 12 pairs of cranial nerves, which originate directly from the brain and control various functions in the head and neck. This makes option B the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The human nervous system has a total of 31 pairs of spinal nerves, which originate from the spinal cord and control functions in the body. However, the cranial nerves, which originate directly from the brain, are only 12 pairs, not 31 or any other number. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: The myelin sheath helps in:
questions.explanation_correct: The myelin sheath helps in faster conduction of nerve impulses. This is because the myelin sheath acts as an insulator, allowing electrical signals to travel more quickly along the axon of a neuron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The myelin sheath does not help in receiving impulses, producing neurotransmitters, or storing information. The myelin sheath is a fatty layer that wraps around the axon of a neuron, and its primary function is to facilitate the rapid transmission of electrical signals along the neuron.

questions.question_text: The fight or flight response is controlled by the:
questions.explanation_correct: The fight or flight response is controlled by the sympathetic nervous system, which prepares the body to respond to stressful or dangerous situations. This includes increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing rate to prepare the body for physical action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fight or flight response is not controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for rest and digestion. It is also not controlled by the somatic nervous system, which controls voluntary movements. The fight or flight response is an automatic, involuntary reaction that is controlled by the sympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system.

questions.question_text: The correct pathway of a reflex arc is:

options.text: Effector -> Motor neuron -> Relay neuron -> Sensory neuron -> Receptor
Receptor -> Sensory neuron -> Relay neuron -> Motor neuron -> Effector
Receptor -> Motor neuron -> Relay neuron -> Sensory neuron -> Effector
Sensory neuron -> Receptor -> Motor neuron -> Effector

questions.explanation_correct: The correct pathway of a reflex arc is Receptor -> Sensory neuron -> Relay neuron -> Motor neuron -> Effector. This is because a reflex arc involves a quick, automatic response to a stimulus, where the signal from the receptor travels to the spinal cord (relay neuron) and then directly to the muscle (motor neuron and effector).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly represent the sequence of a reflex arc. Option A has the order of the neurons reversed, option C has the motor neuron and sensory neuron switched, and option D is missing the relay neuron which is a crucial part of the reflex arc pathway.

questions.question_text: Rods in the retina are responsible for:
questions.explanation_correct: Rods in the retina are responsible for vision in dim light. They are sensitive to low levels of light and allow us to see in dark or low-light conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Vision in dim light. Rods are specialized light-detecting cells in the retina that are sensitive to low levels of light, allowing us to see in the dark or in dimly lit environments. They do not detect color (which is the function of cones) or provide sharp, detailed vision (which is the function of the fovea, a region with high cone density). Rods also do not contribute to depth perception.

questions.question_text: The ability of the eye to change lens shape for focusing is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The ability of the eye to change the shape of the lens in order to focus on objects at different distances is called accommodation. This allows the eye to clearly see both near and far objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Accommodation. Accommodation refers to the eye's ability to change the shape of the lens to focus light properly on the retina. This allows the eye to see both near and far objects clearly. The other options are not correct - refraction is the bending of light as it passes through the cornea and lens, adaptation is the eye's adjustment to different light levels, and astigmatism is a condition where the eye is unable to focus light properly due to an irregular cornea shape.

questions.question_text: Myopia (short-sightedness) is corrected using:
questions.explanation_correct: Myopia, or short-sightedness, is caused by the eyeball being too long or the lens being too curved. A concave lens can correct this by bending the light rays inward, allowing them to focus correctly on the retina at the back of the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex lenses are used to correct farsightedness, where distant objects appear blurred. Cylindrical lenses are used to correct astigmatism, where the eye has an irregular curvature. Bifocal lenses have two different lens powers, one for near vision and one for far vision, and are not the best choice for correcting myopia alone.

questions.question_text: The three tiny bones in the middle ear are called:
questions.explanation_correct: The three small bones in the middle ear are called the ossicles, which are the malleus, incus, and stapes. These bones help transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear, allowing us to hear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is option B, the malleus, incus, and stapes, which are the three small bones in the middle ear. The other options are incorrect as they refer to different parts of the ear - option A is for the parts of the inner ear, option C is for the external ear, and option D is for the vestibular system in the inner ear.

questions.question_text: The brain is protected by three membranes called:
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is protected by three membranes called the meninges, which are the dura mater, arachnoid mater, and pia mater. These protective layers surround and cushion the brain, preventing it from getting damaged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is not protected by the peritoneum, pericardium, or pleura. These are membranes that cover other organs in the body, not the brain. The correct answer is the meninges, which are the three specialized membranes that encase and protect the brain and spinal cord.

questions.question_text: At rest, a neuron is negatively charged inside. This is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The resting potential is the negative charge inside a neuron when it is not actively transmitting an electrical signal. This is the normal, stable state of the neuron when it is at rest and not firing an action potential.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The action potential is the rapid change in electrical charge that travels along the neuron to transmit a signal. The synaptic potential is the change in charge at the synapse (connection) between two neurons. The threshold potential is the minimum level of stimulation needed to trigger an action potential. None of these describe the stable, resting state of the neuron, which is what the question is asking about.

questions.question_text: The hypothalamus is important for:
questions.explanation_correct: The hypothalamus is important for linking the nervous and endocrine systems. It acts as a bridge between the two systems, allowing the brain to coordinate the body's hormonal responses through the pituitary gland.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hypothalamus is not primarily responsible for voluntary muscle control or vision. Instead, it plays a key role in coordinating the nervous and endocrine systems, which is why option B is the correct answer. The hypothalamus sends signals to the pituitary gland, which then releases hormones that regulate various bodily functions.

questions.question_text: The blind spot in the eye is where:

options.text: The optic nerve leaves the eye (no photoreceptors)

questions.explanation_correct: The blind spot in the eye is where the optic nerve leaves the eye, as there are no photoreceptors (light-sensitive cells) in that area. This is the point where the optic nerve connects the eye to the brain, allowing visual information to be processed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The blind spot is not where most cones are concentrated, as cones are responsible for color vision and are found throughout the retina. It is also not where light enters the eye, as the entire surface of the eye is exposed to light. The blind spot is also not where the lens is thickest, as the lens focuses light onto the retina.

questions.question_text: Balance and equilibrium are maintained by the:
questions.explanation_correct: The vestibular apparatus, consisting of the semicircular canals, is responsible for maintaining balance and equilibrium in the human body. It helps detect the body's position and movements, allowing the nervous system to make the necessary adjustments to keep the body stable and balanced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cochlea is responsible for hearing, not for maintaining balance and equilibrium. The eardrum and external ear are also not involved in balance control. The vestibular apparatus, which includes the semicircular canals, is the part of the inner ear that detects the body's movements and position, allowing the nervous system to keep the body balanced and stable.

questions.question_text: A conditioned reflex differs from a natural reflex because it is:
questions.explanation_correct: A conditioned reflex is learned through experience, unlike a natural reflex which is inborn and automatic. Conditioned reflexes are acquired after an organism associates a new stimulus with a natural reflex, such as Pavlov's dogs learning to salivate at the sound of a bell before food is presented.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A conditioned reflex is not inborn like a natural reflex, but rather learned through experience. It is also not necessarily faster than a natural reflex. Additionally, conditioned reflexes are not controlled solely by the spinal cord, but rather involve the brain's cerebral cortex as well.

questions.question_text: Cataract is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Cataract is caused by clouding of the lens inside the eye. This prevents light from properly focusing on the retina, leading to blurred vision.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cataract is not caused by elongation of the eyeball, damage to the retina, or an irregular cornea. These conditions have different effects on vision. Cataract specifically refers to the lens becoming cloudy, which interferes with light reaching the retina and causes vision problems.

questions.question_text: Saltatory conduction occurs in:
questions.explanation_correct: Saltatory conduction occurs in myelinated neurons. The myelin sheath around the axon of a neuron acts as an insulator, allowing electrical impulses to jump from one node of Ranvier to the next, instead of traveling continuously along the axon. This 'saltatory' conduction is faster and more efficient than continuous conduction in non-myelinated neurons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saltatory conduction does not occur in non-myelinated neurons, muscles, or all neurons equally. It is a specific type of electrical impulse transmission that only happens in myelinated neurons. The myelin sheath around the axon allows for faster, more efficient conduction of the impulse compared to non-myelinated neurons where the impulse has to travel continuously along the axon.

questions.question_text: The central nervous system consists of:
questions.explanation_correct: The central nervous system consists of the brain and the spinal cord. The brain coordinates the nervous system's control of the body, while the spinal cord acts as the main information highway, transmitting signals between the brain and the rest of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The central nervous system does not consist of just the brain, nor does it consist solely of nerves or sensory organs. The brain and spinal cord together make up the central nervous system, which is responsible for processing and coordinating information from the nervous system as a whole. The nerves and sensory organs are part of the peripheral nervous system, which connects the central nervous system to the rest of the body.

questions.question_text: How many pairs of spinal nerves are there?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 31 pairs of spinal nerves. The spinal cord, which is part of the central nervous system, has 31 pairs of spinal nerves that connect it to the rest of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (12 pairs) and Option B (21 pairs) are incorrect because the spinal cord has 31 pairs of spinal nerves, not 12 or 21. Option D (43 pairs) is also incorrect as there are only 31 pairs of spinal nerves. The spinal cord has 31 pairs of spinal nerves that emerge between the vertebrae and connect the spinal cord to the rest of the body.

questions.question_text: The colored part of the eye that controls light entry is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The iris is the colored part of the eye that controls the amount of light entering the eye by adjusting the size of the pupil, which is the opening in the center of the iris.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pupil is the opening in the center of the iris that controls the amount of light entering the eye, not the colored part itself. The cornea is the clear, curved front part of the eye that helps focus light, and the retina is the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye that converts light into electrical signals for the brain to interpret.

questions.question_text: The Eustachian tube connects the middle ear to the:
questions.explanation_correct: The Eustachian tube connects the middle ear to the pharynx (the back of the throat) to equalize the air pressure between the middle ear and the outside environment. This is necessary for proper functioning of the eardrum and hearing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Eustachian tube does not connect the middle ear to the inner ear, outer ear, or brain. The inner ear contains the cochlea for hearing and the vestibular system for balance, while the outer ear includes the visible part of the ear and the ear canal. The Eustachian tube specifically links the middle ear with the pharynx in the throat to regulate air pressure.

questions.question_text: Hypermetropia (long-sightedness) is corrected using:
questions.explanation_correct: Hypermetropia, or long-sightedness, is corrected using a convex lens because it helps to bend the light and focus it properly on the retina, allowing the person to see distant objects clearly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hypermetropia is not corrected using a concave lens, as that would make the light rays diverge, making distant objects appear even more blurred. Cylindrical lenses are used to correct astigmatism, not hypermetropia. Contact lenses can be used to correct hypermetropia, but they are not the only option - convex lenses in the form of eyeglasses are also commonly used.

questions.question_text: Dendrites carry impulses away from the cell body.
questions.explanation_correct: Dendrites carry impulses towards the cell body, not away from it. They are the short, branched extensions of the neuron that receive signals from other neurons or sensory receptors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect statement that 'dendrites carry impulses away from the cell body' is a common misconception. In fact, dendrites are responsible for receiving and transmitting electrical signals towards the cell body, which then sends the impulses along the axon to other neurons or effector organs.

questions.question_text: The cerebrum is responsible for thinking and memory.
questions.explanation_correct: The cerebrum is responsible for thinking, memory, and voluntary actions. This is because the cerebrum is the largest part of the brain and is involved in higher cognitive functions like processing information, reasoning, and decision-making.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because the cerebrum is not responsible for involuntary actions like breathing or heartbeat. Those functions are controlled by the medulla oblongata, which is a different part of the brain. The cerebrum is specifically involved in voluntary, conscious activities like thinking, remembering, and controlling voluntary movements.

questions.question_text: Reflex actions involve conscious thought.
questions.explanation_correct: Reflex actions are quick, automatic responses that do not involve conscious thought. They occur through reflex arcs that bypass the brain and allow the body to react instantly to stimuli.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reflex actions are not the result of conscious thought. They are quick, automatic responses triggered by the nervous system, which bypasses the brain. The body reacts instantly to a stimulus through a reflex arc, without any conscious decision-making involved.

questions.question_text: Cones are responsible for color vision.
questions.explanation_correct: Cones are responsible for color vision because they are specialized photoreceptor cells in the retina that detect color. Cones require brighter light to function, and they allow us to see colors and fine details.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be that cones are not responsible for color vision. This is because cones are the photoreceptors in the retina that are responsible for detecting color. Rods, on the other hand, are responsible for detecting brightness and dim light, but they do not detect color.

questions.question_text: The parasympathetic nervous system increases heart rate.
questions.explanation_correct: The parasympathetic nervous system is responsible for the 'rest and digest' functions of the body, which means it slows down the heart rate. The sympathetic nervous system, on the other hand, is responsible for the 'fight or flight' response, which increases the heart rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many students may think the parasympathetic nervous system increases heart rate, but this is incorrect. The parasympathetic nervous system actually decreases heart rate and promotes relaxation, while the sympathetic nervous system increases heart rate and prepares the body for action.

questions.question_text: The lens of the eye is made flatter for viewing distant objects.
questions.explanation_correct: The lens of the eye becomes more curved (convex) to view distant objects, and flatter to view closer objects. This change in the curvature of the lens is called accommodation and allows the eye to focus on objects at different distances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common misconception is that the lens becomes flatter to view distant objects. However, this is incorrect. The lens actually becomes more curved (convex) to focus the light and form a clear image of distant objects on the retina. The flattening of the lens occurs when viewing closer objects, to allow for proper focusing.

questions.question_text: Sound waves are converted to nerve impulses in the cochlea.
questions.explanation_correct: Sound waves are converted to nerve impulses in the cochlea, which is the hearing part of the inner ear. The cochlea contains hair cells that convert the vibrations of sound waves into electrical signals that can be interpreted by the brain as sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that sound waves are converted to nerve impulses in the outer or middle ear, but this is not correct. The outer and middle ear simply transmit the sound vibrations to the inner ear, where the cochlea is responsible for converting them into electrical signals that the brain can understand.

questions.question_text: Neurotransmitters carry impulses across the synapse.
questions.explanation_correct: Neurotransmitters are chemical messengers that carry electrical impulses across the synapse, the tiny gap between two neurons. When an impulse reaches the end of one neuron, it triggers the release of neurotransmitters, which then bind to receptors on the next neuron, allowing the impulse to continue its journey through the nervous system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common misconception is that neurons themselves carry the impulses through the nervous system. However, neurons use electrical signals to transmit information, while neurotransmitters are the chemicals that pass the signal across the synaptic gap between neurons. Without these neurotransmitters, the electrical impulse would not be able to travel from one neuron to the next.

questions.question_text: The spinal cord can control reflex actions without brain involvement.
questions.explanation_correct: The spinal cord can indeed control reflex actions without the involvement of the brain. Reflex actions are quick, automatic responses that occur through reflex arcs, which are neural pathways that connect the sensory receptors to the spinal cord and then to the muscles. The spinal cord can process these reflex actions independently, without the need for the brain to intervene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that the brain is always required to control all body actions, including reflexes. However, this is not the case. Reflex actions are a type of automatic response that the spinal cord can process and coordinate without the brain's involvement. The spinal cord has the necessary neural pathways and processing capabilities to handle these quick, involuntary responses to stimuli.

questions.question_text: The semicircular canals detect rotational movement.
questions.explanation_correct: The semicircular canals in the inner ear are part of the vestibular system, which detects rotational and angular movements of the head. This information is sent to the brain to help maintain balance and spatial orientation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think the semicircular canals detect linear movement, but this is not correct. The semicircular canals are specifically designed to detect rotational movements of the head, which is essential for maintaining balance and coordinating body movements.

questions.question_text: The long fiber of a neuron that transmits impulses away from the cell body is the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The axon is the long, thin fiber that extends from the cell body (soma) of a neuron and transmits electrical impulses away from the cell body to other neurons, muscles, or glands. This long fiber is specialized for the rapid transmission of signals throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'axon'. The axon is the part of the neuron that transmits electrical impulses away from the cell body, while the dendrites are the structures that receive impulses from other neurons. The cell body (soma) contains the nucleus and is where most of the metabolic activity of the neuron takes place.

questions.question_text: The part of the brain that controls balance is the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The cerebellum is the part of the brain that controls balance and coordination of body movements. This is because the cerebellum receives sensory information about the body's position and movements, and uses this to coordinate muscle activity and maintain balance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cerebellum'. The cerebellum is the part of the brain that is responsible for controlling balance and coordination of our body movements. It receives information from the inner ear and other sensory organs about the body's position and movements, and uses this information to adjust muscle activity and maintain balance. The cerebrum, which is the largest part of the brain, is responsible for higher functions like thinking, memory, and voluntary actions, but it does not directly control balance.

questions.question_text: The gap between two neurons is called a _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The gap between two neurons where chemical signals are transmitted is called a synapse. This connection allows electrical impulses to be passed from one neuron to the next, enabling communication within the nervous system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'synapse'. This refers to the small gap between two neurons where neurotransmitters are released to carry the electrical signal from one cell to the next. It is not the 'axon' (the long part of the neuron that transmits the signal) or the 'dendrite' (the part that receives the signal).

questions.question_text: The light-sensitive layer of the eye containing rods and cones is the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye that contains the light-detecting rod and cone cells is called the retina. This layer is responsible for converting light into electrical signals that can be interpreted by the brain, allowing us to see images.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'retina'. The retina is the innermost layer of the eye that contains the light-sensitive rod and cone cells. These cells convert the light entering the eye into electrical signals that are sent to the brain, allowing us to perceive images. Other parts of the eye, like the cornea, lens, and iris, help focus and control the amount of light reaching the retina, but the retina itself is the layer that actually detects the light.

questions.question_text: The pathway of a reflex action is called a reflex _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The pathway of a reflex action is called a reflex arc because it involves a loop or circuit of nerves that carry the impulse from the receptor to the spinal cord and back to the effector (muscle or gland).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'arc'. A reflex arc is the pathway that a reflex action follows. It includes the receptor, sensory neuron, central nervous system, motor neuron, and effector. This coordinated pathway allows for a quick, automatic response to a stimulus, which is the defining feature of a reflex action.

questions.question_text: Short-sightedness is also called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Myopia, or short-sightedness, is the correct term because it refers to the condition where the eye's lens focuses light in front of the retina, leading to blurred distant vision. This happens when the eyeball is too long or the cornea is too curved, and is the most common refractive error in the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'myopia'. The term 'short-sightedness' is not technically correct, as it does not provide the specific medical name for this eye condition. Myopia is the proper term that describes the visual impairment where distant objects appear blurred due to the eye's inability to focus light properly on the retina.

questions.question_text: The three small bones in the middle ear are collectively called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The three small bones in the middle ear are called ossicles. This term refers to the malleus (hammer), incus (anvil), and stapes (stirrup) - the three tiny bones that transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'ossicles'. The three small bones in the middle ear are not called something like 'eardrums' or 'earlobes'. They are the specialized bones that play a key role in hearing by conveying sound vibrations from the outer ear to the inner ear. The specific term for this trio of bones is 'ossicles'.

questions.question_text: The fluid that protects the brain and spinal cord is called _____ fluid.
questions.explanation_correct: The brain and spinal cord are protected by a special fluid called cerebrospinal fluid. This fluid cushions and protects the delicate nervous system tissues from injury.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'cerebrospinal'. The brain and spinal cord are surrounded by a fluid called cerebrospinal fluid, which protects and cushions the nervous system. This fluid is produced in the ventricles of the brain and circulates around the brain and spinal cord, providing a layer of protection.

questions.question_text: The division of the autonomic nervous system that prepares the body for stress is the _____ division.
questions.explanation_correct: The sympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system is responsible for preparing the body for stressful or emergency situations. It triggers the 'fight or flight' response, increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing rate to get the body ready for action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The parasympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system is responsible for 'rest and digest' functions, slowing down the body's activities. The sympathetic division, on the other hand, prepares the body for stress and emergency situations by increasing heart rate, breathing, and blood flow. So the correct answer is the 'sympathetic' division of the autonomic nervous system.

questions.question_text: The ability of the eye to adjust lens shape for focusing is called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The eye's ability to adjust the shape of the lens in order to focus light properly on the retina is called accommodation. This allows the eye to see clearly at different distances, by bending the lens to focus the light correctly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'accommodation'. This refers to the eye's ability to change the shape of the lens in order to focus light properly on the retina. This adjustment allows the eye to see clearly at different distances. The lens becomes more curved for close objects and flatter for distant objects, bending the light to focus it correctly.

questions.question_text: The coiled structure in the inner ear that detects sound is the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The cochlea is the coiled, spiral-shaped structure located in the inner ear that is responsible for detecting sound vibrations and converting them into electrical impulses that the brain can interpret as sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'cochlea', which refers to the coiled structure in the inner ear that detects sound. This is the correct answer because the cochlea is the part of the inner ear that contains the sensory receptors for hearing. It converts the mechanical vibrations of sound waves into electrical signals that the brain can understand as sound.

questions.question_text: Impulses jump from node to node in myelinated neurons through _____ conduction.
questions.explanation_correct: Impulses jump from node to node in myelinated neurons through saltatory conduction. This is because the myelin sheath acts as an insulator, allowing the impulses to 'jump' quickly from one node of Ranvier to the next, speeding up the transmission of signals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'saltatory'. Impulses in myelinated neurons do not travel through continuous conduction. Instead, they jump from one node of Ranvier to the next along the myelin sheath, a process called saltatory conduction. This is faster than continuous conduction because the impulse does not have to travel along the entire length of the axon.

questions.question_text: Arrange the components of a reflex arc in correct order:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of the components of a reflex arc is: Receptor -> Sensory neuron -> Relay neuron -> Motor neuron -> Effector. This is because the process starts with a stimulus detected by the receptor, which then transmits the signal through the sensory neuron to the relay neuron in the spinal cord or brain. The relay neuron then sends the signal to the motor neuron, which finally causes the effector (muscle or gland) to respond quickly and automatically.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Motor neuron -> Sensory neuron -> Relay neuron -> Receptor -> Effector. This is not correct because the reflex arc starts with the receptor detecting the stimulus, which then sends the signal through the sensory neuron to the relay neuron in the central nervous system. The relay neuron then communicates with the motor neuron, which causes the effector to respond. The motor neuron does not initiate the reflex action.

questions.question_text: Arrange the path of light through the eye:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Cornea, Pupil, Lens, Vitreous humor, Retina because this is the exact path that light takes as it enters the eye and reaches the retina, where the image is formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order may be, for example, Retina, Cornea, Pupil, Lens, Vitreous humor. This is not correct because light first enters the eye through the cornea, then passes through the pupil, lens, and vitreous humor before reaching the retina at the back of the eye. The light path must follow the correct sequence for the image to be formed properly on the retina.

questions.question_text: Arrange the path of sound through the ear:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Pinna, Ear canal, Ear drum, Ear ossicles, Cochlea because sound waves first enter through the outer ear (pinna), travel through the ear canal, then vibrate the eardrum, which in turn moves the three small bones (ossicles) in the middle ear, and finally the vibrations reach the cochlea in the inner ear where they are detected.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to put the cochlea first. This is wrong because the cochlea is located in the inner ear, and sound waves need to travel through the outer and middle ear before reaching the inner ear and the cochlea. The correct path is from the outer ear (pinna) to the ear canal, then the eardrum, the ear ossicles, and finally the cochlea in the inner ear, where the sound vibrations are detected and converted into electrical signals that the brain can understand.

questions.question_text: Arrange the events of synaptic transmission in order:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of events in synaptic transmission is: Impulse arrives at axon terminal, Vesicles release neurotransmitter, Neurotransmitter binds to receptors, Impulse generated in next neuron. This is the sequence in which the electrical signal is converted to a chemical signal and then back to an electrical signal in the next neuron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Neurotransmitter binds to receptors, Impulse arrives at axon terminal, Vesicles release neurotransmitter, Impulse generated in next neuron. This is wrong because the neurotransmitter can only bind to receptors after it has been released from the vesicles, which happens when the electrical impulse reaches the axon terminal.

questions.question_text: Arrange the brain parts from largest to smallest:
questions.explanation_correct: The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain, followed by the cerebellum, and then the medulla oblongata. This is because the cerebrum is responsible for higher brain functions like thinking, memory, and voluntary actions, while the cerebellum coordinates balance and movement, and the medulla oblongata controls basic life functions like breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from largest to smallest brain parts is: Cerebrum, Cerebellum, Medulla oblongata. Some students may think the medulla oblongata is the largest, but it is actually the smallest of the three main brain parts. The medulla oblongata is responsible for basic life functions like breathing and heart rate, while the cerebrum and cerebellum handle more complex processes.

questions.question_text: How does a dendrite differ from an axon in terms of function?

options.text: Dendrite transmits impulses away from the cell body; axon receives impulses
Dendrite receives impulses towards the cell body; axon transmits impulses away from it
Both dendrite and axon receive impulses equally
Dendrite produces neurotransmitters; axon absorbs them

questions.explanation_correct: Dendrites are short, branched extensions that receive impulses from other neurons or sensory receptors and carry them towards the cell body. In contrast, the axon is a single, long fibre that transmits impulses away from the cell body towards the next neuron or an effector organ. This directional difference is fundamental to the one-way transmission of nerve impulses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the roles of dendrite and axon. Option C is wrong because dendrites and axons have distinct, complementary functions  they do not receive impulses equally. Option D incorrectly assigns neurotransmitter production to dendrites; neurotransmitters are actually released from the axon terminals at the synapse.

questions.question_text: How does the cerebrum differ from the cerebellum in terms of primary function?

options.text: Cerebrum controls involuntary actions; cerebellum controls voluntary actions
Cerebrum controls thinking and memory; cerebellum controls balance and coordination
Cerebrum controls balance; cerebellum controls breathing
Both control identical functions but in different hemispheres

questions.explanation_correct: The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain and is responsible for higher cognitive functions such as thinking, reasoning, memory, and voluntary muscular actions. The cerebellum, located at the back and below the cerebrum, is primarily responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and coordination of voluntary movements. These two brain regions handle fundamentally different categories of function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the roles  the cerebrum handles voluntary actions and higher thought, not involuntary ones. Option C is wrong because balance is a cerebellar function and breathing is controlled by the medulla oblongata, not the cerebellum. Option D is incorrect because the cerebrum and cerebellum are structurally and functionally distinct parts of the brain.

questions.question_text: How does the sympathetic nervous system differ from the parasympathetic nervous system in its effect on the heart?

options.text: Sympathetic decreases heart rate; parasympathetic increases heart rate
Both increase heart rate equally during stress
Sympathetic increases heart rate; parasympathetic decreases heart rate
Neither division has any effect on heart rate

questions.explanation_correct: The sympathetic nervous system is the 'fight or flight' division that increases heart rate, dilates pupils, and prepares the body for emergency action. The parasympathetic nervous system is the 'rest and digest' division that slows down the heart rate, constricts pupils, and promotes relaxation. These two divisions of the autonomic nervous system have antagonistic (opposing) effects on the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the effects of each division. Option B is incorrect because the two divisions have opposing, not identical, effects on the heart. Option D is wrong because both divisions actively regulate heart rate  the sympathetic speeds it up and the parasympathetic slows it down.

questions.question_text: How do rods differ from cones in the retina in terms of the type of vision they enable?

options.text: Rods enable colour vision; cones enable dim-light vision
Rods enable vision in dim light; cones enable colour vision in bright light
Both rods and cones function identically under all lighting conditions
Rods detect sound vibrations; cones detect light

questions.explanation_correct: Rods are highly sensitive photoreceptor cells that function best in dim or low light conditions (scotopic vision), enabling black-and-white vision. Cones, on the other hand, require bright light (photopic vision) and are responsible for colour perception and visual acuity. Rods are more numerous and distributed across the peripheral retina, while cones are concentrated in the fovea.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the functions of rods and cones. Option C is incorrect because rods and cones have distinctly different sensitivities and roles. Option D is absurd  rods are photoreceptors in the eye and do not detect sound vibrations; that is the function of hair cells in the cochlea of the ear.

questions.question_text: How does a reflex action differ from a voluntary action in terms of the role of the brain?

options.text: Reflex actions are processed by the cerebrum; voluntary actions bypass the brain
Reflex actions are controlled at the spinal cord level without brain involvement; voluntary actions require cerebral processing
Both reflex and voluntary actions always require the cerebrum
Reflex actions are slower because they travel a longer pathway through the brain

questions.explanation_correct: Reflex actions are rapid, automatic responses that are processed at the level of the spinal cord through a reflex arc, without requiring conscious involvement of the brain. Voluntary actions, in contrast, require the cerebral cortex (cerebrum) of the brain to process information, make decisions, and initiate the motor response. This is why reflexes are much faster than voluntary actions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the pathways  reflexes bypass the brain, not voluntary actions. Option C is wrong because reflexes specifically do not require cerebral involvement. Option D is incorrect because reflex actions are faster, not slower, precisely because they take a shorter pathway through the spinal cord rather than travelling to the brain.

questions.question_text: A nerve cell has a long fibre covered with a fatty insulating sheath and transmits impulses at high speed by jumping from node to node. This description best identifies:

options.text: A relay neuron in the spinal cord
A dendrite of a motor neuron

questions.explanation_correct: The description mentions a fatty insulating sheath (myelin sheath) and impulse transmission by jumping from node to node (saltatory conduction at the nodes of Ranvier). These are defining features of a myelinated neuron. The myelin sheath, made of Schwann cells in the PNS, insulates the axon and enables faster saltatory conduction compared to continuous conduction in non-myelinated neurons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because a non-myelinated neuron lacks the fatty insulating sheath described. Option C, a relay neuron, could be myelinated or non-myelinated  the description specifically points to myelination, not the relay function. Option D is incorrect because dendrites are short, branched structures and do not have the long fibre with myelin sheath described here.

questions.question_text: A brain region controls involuntary vital functions such as heartbeat, breathing rate, and blood pressure. It is located at the base of the brain, continuous with the spinal cord. This region is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The medulla oblongata is located at the base of the brain and is continuous with the spinal cord. It is the control centre for involuntary vital functions including heartbeat, breathing rate, blood pressure, swallowing, and vomiting. The features described  involuntary vital functions and location at the brain's base  are characteristic of the medulla oblongata.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum (Option A) is the seat of higher cognitive functions like thinking and memory, not involuntary vital functions. The cerebellum (Option B) controls balance and coordination of voluntary movements. The hypothalamus (Option D) regulates body temperature, hunger, thirst, and links the nervous system to the endocrine system, but does not directly control heartbeat or breathing rate.

questions.question_text: A structure in the ear is fluid-filled, spiral-shaped, and contains hair cells that convert sound vibrations into nerve impulses. This structure is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The cochlea is the fluid-filled, spiral (snail-shaped) structure in the inner ear that contains the organ of Corti with specialised hair cells. These hair cells are mechanoreceptors that convert sound vibrations transmitted through the ossicles into electrical nerve impulses, which travel via the auditory nerve to the brain for interpretation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Eustachian tube (Option A) connects the middle ear to the pharynx for pressure equalisation and is not spiral-shaped. The semicircular canals (Option B) are fluid-filled but detect rotational movements for balance, not sound. The tympanic membrane (Option D) is the eardrum  a thin membrane that vibrates in response to sound, but it does not contain hair cells or convert vibrations into nerve impulses.

questions.question_text: A part of the eye is transparent, biconvex, and can change its curvature with the help of ciliary muscles to focus light on the retina. This structure is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The crystalline lens of the eye is a transparent, biconvex structure that is attached to the ciliary muscles by suspensory ligaments. The ciliary muscles contract or relax to change the curvature of the lens  a process called accommodation  which allows the eye to focus light on the retina for both near and distant objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea (Option A) is transparent and refracts light but is fixed in shape and does not change curvature for focusing. The iris (Option C) is the coloured, opaque structure that controls the size of the pupil. The vitreous humour (Option D) is a transparent, jelly-like substance that fills the space behind the lens but does not change shape.

questions.question_text: Riya accidentally touches a hot tawa (griddle) while helping her mother in the kitchen. She instantly pulls her hand back even before she consciously feels the pain. Which component of her nervous system primarily controlled this immediate response?

options.text: Cerebrum, because it processes all body movements
Cerebellum, because it coordinates muscle activity
Spinal cord, through a reflex arc
Hypothalamus, because it senses temperature changes

questions.explanation_correct: When Riya touched the hot tawa, pain receptors in her skin detected the harmful stimulus and sent impulses through sensory neurons to the spinal cord. The spinal cord immediately sent impulses through motor neurons to the arm muscles, causing her to withdraw her hand. This entire reflex arc  receptor to sensory neuron to relay neuron (in spinal cord) to motor neuron to effector (muscle)  bypassed the brain, which is why the response was instantaneous and involuntary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum (Option A) processes conscious, voluntary actions and would take longer to respond. The cerebellum (Option B) coordinates balance and smooth movements, not rapid protective reflexes. The hypothalamus (Option D) regulates homeostatic functions like body temperature regulation via hormones, but does not mediate the immediate withdrawal reflex to a hot object.

questions.question_text: Amit, a Class 10 student, complains to the school nurse that he can read his textbook clearly but cannot see the blackboard from the last bench. The nurse suspects a refractive error. What is Amit's likely condition and the corrective lens needed?

options.text: Hypermetropia; corrected with a concave lens
Myopia; corrected with a concave lens
Myopia; corrected with a convex lens
Presbyopia; corrected with a bifocal lens

questions.explanation_correct: Amit can see nearby objects (textbook) clearly but cannot see distant objects (blackboard), which is the hallmark of myopia (short-sightedness). In myopia, the eyeball is too long or the lens is too convex, causing the image of distant objects to form in front of the retina instead of on it. A concave (diverging) lens is used to correct this by spreading the light rays slightly before they enter the eye, so the image shifts back onto the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hypermetropia (Option A) is long-sightedness where nearby objects are blurred  the opposite of Amit's problem. Option C correctly identifies myopia but prescribes the wrong lens; a convex lens would worsen myopia by converging the rays even more. Presbyopia (Option D) is an age-related condition seen in people over 40, not in Class 10 students.

questions.question_text: During a cricket match at school, Arjun suddenly sees the ball flying towards his face. His heart rate shoots up, pupils dilate, and he ducks quickly. After the danger passes, his body gradually calms down  heart rate slows and breathing returns to normal. Which two divisions of the autonomic nervous system acted in sequence?

options.text: Somatic nervous system first, then autonomic
Central nervous system first, then peripheral nervous system

questions.explanation_correct: When Arjun perceived the threat (ball flying towards him), his sympathetic nervous system activated the 'fight or flight' response  increasing heart rate, dilating pupils, and redirecting blood to muscles. Once the danger passed, the parasympathetic nervous system took over with the 'rest and digest' response, slowing the heart rate and returning breathing to normal. These two antagonistic divisions of the autonomic nervous system act in sequence to handle stress and recovery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the correct sequence  the parasympathetic system calms the body after the sympathetic system has responded to stress. Option B incorrectly categorises the divisions; the somatic nervous system controls voluntary skeletal muscles and is not the division responsible for the automatic changes in heart rate and pupils. Option D describes broad categories (CNS and PNS) rather than the specific autonomic divisions involved.

questions.question_text: Priya goes on a holiday trip to Ooty with her family. While travelling on the winding ghat roads, she feels dizzy and nauseous. Her father explains that a part of her inner ear is being overstimulated by the constant turning. Which structure is primarily responsible for detecting these rotational movements?
questions.explanation_correct: The semicircular canals are three fluid-filled, loop-shaped structures in the inner ear arranged in three planes (horizontal, anterior, and posterior). They detect rotational or angular movements of the head. The constant turning on winding ghat roads causes repeated stimulation of the fluid (endolymph) in these canals, sending conflicting signals to the brain compared to what the eyes see, resulting in motion sickness (dizziness and nausea).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cochlea (Option A) is the hearing organ and does not detect rotational movement. The ossicles (Option B) are bones in the middle ear that amplify and transmit sound vibrations. The Eustachian tube (Option D) equalises air pressure between the middle ear and the pharynx; it does not detect movement.

questions.question_text: Meera's grandfather suffered a stroke that damaged a specific region at the back of his brain. After the stroke, he can think and speak normally, but he has difficulty walking in a straight line and his movements are uncoordinated. Which part of the brain was most likely damaged?
questions.explanation_correct: The cerebellum is located at the back of the brain (posterior cranial fossa) and is responsible for coordinating voluntary movements, maintaining balance, and ensuring smooth, precise muscular activity. Damage to the cerebellum results in ataxia  uncoordinated movements, difficulty walking, and loss of balance  exactly matching the symptoms described for Meera's grandfather. His ability to think and speak normally indicates the cerebrum is unaffected.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Damage to the cerebrum (Option A) would impair thinking, memory, speech, or voluntary motor initiation, but his thinking and speech are normal. Damage to the medulla oblongata (Option B) would affect vital involuntary functions like breathing and heartbeat, which could be life-threatening. The hypothalamus (Option C) controls homeostatic functions and hormone regulation; its damage would not specifically cause uncoordinated walking.

questions.question_text: All of the following are examples of reflex actions EXCEPT:

options.text: Blinking when an object approaches the eye
Withdrawing the hand from a hot object
Solving a mathematics problem during an exam
Salivation at the sight of food

questions.explanation_correct: Solving a mathematics problem requires conscious, deliberate thought involving the cerebral cortex of the cerebrum. It is a voluntary action, not a reflex. Blinking (Option A) and hand withdrawal from heat (Option B) are unconditioned (natural) reflexes, while salivation at the sight of food (Option D) is a conditioned reflex. All three of these are automatic responses that do not require conscious thinking, unlike solving a maths problem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Students sometimes confuse any rapid response with a reflex. However, reflexes are defined as automatic, involuntary responses that do not require conscious brain processing. Solving a maths problem clearly requires deliberate thinking and problem-solving by the cerebrum, making it a voluntary action. Options A, B, and D are all genuine reflexes  either natural or conditioned.

questions.question_text: All of the following functions are controlled by the medulla oblongata EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: Thinking and reasoning are higher cognitive functions controlled by the cerebrum (cerebral cortex), not the medulla oblongata. The medulla oblongata is the involuntary control centre located at the base of the brain, responsible for regulating vital autonomic functions such as heartbeat (Option A), breathing rate (Option B), and blood pressure (Option D). Students must distinguish between the roles of the cerebrum (voluntary, conscious functions) and the medulla (involuntary, vital functions).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common misconception is that the medulla oblongata controls all brain functions. In reality, the medulla specifically manages involuntary vital functions. Thinking and reasoning require the cerebral cortex, which is the outer layer of the cerebrum. Options A, B, and D are all genuine functions of the medulla oblongata.

questions.question_text: All of the following are parts of the eye's refractive system that help focus light EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: The optic nerve transmits electrical impulses from the retina to the brain  it plays no role in refracting or focusing light. The cornea (Option A) provides the maximum refraction of light entering the eye. The crystalline lens (Option B) fine-tunes focusing through accommodation. The aqueous humour (Option C) is a transparent fluid between the cornea and the lens that also contributes to refraction. Students often confuse the role of the optic nerve with the refractive structures of the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The optic nerve is part of the neural pathway for vision, not the optical/refractive pathway. It carries processed visual information as nerve impulses from the retina to the visual cortex of the brain. It does not bend or focus light in any way. Options A, B, and C are all transparent refractive media that bend light to focus it on the retina.

questions.question_text: Why does impulse transmission in myelinated neurons occur faster than in non-myelinated neurons?

options.text: Because myelinated neurons are shorter in length
Because the myelin sheath allows the impulse to jump between nodes of Ranvier (saltatory conduction)
Because myelinated neurons have more dendrites to receive impulses
Because myelinated neurons produce stronger neurotransmitters

questions.explanation_correct: The myelin sheath acts as an electrical insulator around the axon, preventing ion exchange across the membrane at myelinated regions. The nerve impulse therefore 'jumps' from one node of Ranvier (gap in the myelin sheath) to the next  a process called saltatory conduction. This jumping mechanism is significantly faster than the continuous point-to-point conduction that occurs in non-myelinated neurons, where the impulse must depolarise every segment of the axon membrane sequentially.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect  the speed difference is not due to neuron length but due to the mode of conduction. Option C is wrong because the number of dendrites does not determine conduction speed along the axon. Option D is incorrect because myelin affects axonal impulse speed, not neurotransmitter strength at the synapse.

questions.question_text: Why does a person experience temporary hearing difficulty when ascending to a high altitude in an aeroplane?

options.text: Because the cochlea stops converting sound vibrations into nerve impulses at high altitude
Because the semicircular canals become overactive and suppress hearing
Because unequal air pressure across the eardrum restricts its vibration, and the Eustachian tube needs to equalise this pressure
Because the ossicles in the middle ear expand due to lower pressure

questions.explanation_correct: As altitude increases, the atmospheric pressure outside the ear decreases while the pressure in the middle ear remains the same. This unequal pressure across the tympanic membrane (eardrum) restricts its ability to vibrate freely in response to sound waves, causing a feeling of blocked ears and reduced hearing. The Eustachian tube, which connects the middle ear to the pharynx, opens during swallowing or yawning to allow air to enter or leave the middle ear, equalising the pressure and restoring normal hearing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because the cochlea functions independently of altitude. Option B is incorrect because the semicircular canals detect balance and do not suppress hearing function. Option D is incorrect because the ossicles are bones and do not expand or contract with pressure changes  the issue is with the eardrum and air pressure, not the ossicles themselves.

questions.question_text: Why are reflex actions faster than voluntary actions?

options.text: Because reflex actions use thicker neurons that conduct impulses more quickly
Because the reflex arc pathway involves the spinal cord and bypasses the brain, resulting in a shorter neural pathway
Because reflex actions do not require any neurons at all
Because the muscles involved in reflexes are inherently stronger than those in voluntary actions

questions.explanation_correct: Reflex actions are faster because the neural pathway (reflex arc) goes only as far as the spinal cord, where the sensory information is immediately relayed to motor neurons without waiting for the brain to process and decide on a response. In voluntary actions, the sensory impulse must travel all the way to the cerebral cortex in the brain, be consciously processed, and then a motor command must be sent back to the muscles  a much longer pathway that takes more time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the speed advantage is due to the shorter pathway, not thicker neurons. Option C is wrong because reflex actions absolutely do involve neurons  sensory, relay, and motor neurons form the reflex arc. Option D is incorrect because the speed difference relates to neural processing time and pathway length, not muscle strength.
